The final took place at [[Ullevaal Stadion]] in [[Oslo]] on 22 October 1989. [[Viking FK|Viking]] were in their 8th final (3 wins and 4 runners-up), while [[Molde FK|Molde]] were in their second final after losing the 1982 final against [[SK Brann|Brann]] and therefore had the chance to win the first trophy in the club's history. The first final between the two teams ended with a 2–2 draw. A replay was played on the following Sunday on 29 October and ended with a 2–1 win for Viking who became Norwegian Champions for the fourth time. ==Route to the final== {| class=wikitable width=100% style="text-align:center" |- valign=top !colspan=3 width=45%|Viking!!width=10%|Round!!colspan=3 width=45%|Molde{{cite web |url=https://www.moldefk.no/om-klubben/var-historie/1980-1989/1989 |title= Molde FK 1989 |work=moldefk.no|publisher=Molde FK |accessdate=3 December 2018 |language=Norwegian}} |- valign=top |[[Klepp IL|Klepp]] (D3)

{{Infobox stadium | name = Abrankese Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = [[Kumasi]], [[Ashanti Region|Ashanti]], [[Ghana]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 2007 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Medeama SC]]
[[Ghana national football team]] | capacity = 12,000 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Anane Boateng Sports Stadium''' is a [[Multi-purpose stadium|multi-use stadium]] in [[Kumasi]], built by Mr Kwabena Kess the C.E.O of Kessben Group of Companies [[Ghana]]. It is used mostly for [[Association football|football]] matches and served as a gathering grounds for thousands of people and members mostly Moment of Glory Prayer Army(MOGPA).The stadium is the home stadium of [[Medeama SC]] of the [[Ghana Premier League]]. The stadium holds 12,000 spectators and opened in 2007. ==External links== *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/ghana.shtml Stadium information] {{coord|6.704|N|1.645734|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Ghana]] [[Category:Kumasi]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ghana]] {{Ghana-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Alumni Arena | nickname = | image = | location = 175 Webster Road
[[Amherst, New York|Amherst, NY]] 14221 | coordinates = {{coord|43|00|00|N|78|46|52|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1978 | built = | opened = December 3, 1982 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University at Buffalo]] | operator = [[University at Buffalo]] | surface = Multi-surface | construction_cost = $26,309,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|26309000|1982}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Robert Trayham Coles | structural engineer = Sargent Webster Crenshaw & Folley | former_names = | tenants = [[Buffalo Bulls]]
(men's and women's Basketball) ([[NCAA]]) | seating_capacity = 6,100 |}} '''Alumni Arena''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Amherst, New York]]. The arena is home to the [[State University of New York at Buffalo]] men's and women's [[basketball]] teams, the women's [[volleyball]] team, and [[collegiate wrestling|wrestling]] team.{{cite web|url=http://www.ubbulls.com/facilities/alumni_arena|title=State University of New York at Buffalo: Facilities: Alumni Arena|publisher=University at Buffalo Athletics|date=2014|accessdate=19 December 2014}} The facility currently seats 6,100 people. ==Description== "The Recreation and Athletics Complex (RAC) on the University's [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York#North Campus|North Campus]] includes Alumni Arena, a $12.5 million Phase II Building and a $1.5 million outdoor playing fields complex." "Alumni Arena's main gymnasium is home to the Bulls men's and women's [[Buffalo Bulls#Men's basketball|basketball]] teams, [[Buffalo Bulls#Other men's sports|wrestling]] team and the women's [[Buffalo Bulls#Women's sports|volleyball]] team." "The largest "free-floating" hardwood floor in the United States at the time it was built, it features basketball, volleyball and badminton courts circled by a 200-meter track and seating for 6,100 spectators following renovations during the summer of 2004." The arena used to seat more than 8,000 people, but a renovation project funded by the Blue & White club reduced the seating to 6,100 by eliminating bleachers and adding chairbacks. The [[student section]] was relocated with the renovations. Before the renovations, the students used to generally sit behind the scorer's table, from baseline to baseline, except immediately behind the players' benches. [[Syracuse University|Syracuse's]] [[Carrier Dome]] is the only on-campus college basketball facility in the state that is larger. The volleyball court was constructed for the [[Universiade|World University Games]] in 1993. "The building includes three levels of offices, locker rooms, equipment and training-therapy rooms, seminar rooms, and racquetball courts." "The Phase II Building on the north side of Alumni Arena has an Olympic-sized swimming pool and a separate diving well, a triple gymnasium, and dance studio." "Other areas are a wrestling practice room, two weight-training rooms (a fitness center and a varsity weight room), additional racquetball and squash courts, an erg room, and an aerobics room." Behind Alumni Arena, a playing fields complex provides lighted outdoor space for several sports, including soccer, field hockey, softball, tennis, basketball, handball and archery. In 2011, the lighting and sound systems in the arena were upgraded to state-of-the-art quality.{{cite web|url=http://www.ubbulls.com/general/releases/2011-12/Alumni_Arena_Upgrades|title=UB Athletics announces upgrades to Alumni Arena|publisher=State University of New York at Buffalo|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=19 December 2014}} A new video and scoring system was also installed. On February 3, 2012, the [[Harlem Globetrotters]] played on the Bulls court.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} On August 22, 2013, President [[Barack Obama]] spoke to a sold-out crowd at Alumni Arena about the rising costs of college tuition.{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/city-region/obama-to-speak-at-ub-alumni-arena-next-thursday-20130815|title=White House confirms Obama visit to UB: Will speak at Alumni Arena in the morning|publisher=The Buffalo News|date=15 August 2013|author=Zremski, Jerry|accessdate=19 December 2014}}{{cite web|title=Remarks by the President on College Affordability -- Buffalo, NY|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/08/22/remarks-president-college-affordability-buffalo-ny|publisher=White House|accessdate=27 August 2013}}{{cite news|title=As President Obama talks college affordability, Buffalo's program looks to be a model|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/higher-education/as-president-obama-talks-college-affordability-buffalos-program-looks-to-be-a-model/2013/08/22/bcd166b8-0af4-11e3-89fe-abb4a5067014_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822143916/http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/higher-education/as-president-obama-talks-college-affordability-buffalos-program-looks-to-be-a-model/2013/08/22/bcd166b8-0af4-11e3-89fe-abb4a5067014_story.html|archive-date=22 August 2013|accessdate=27 August 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=22 August 2013|deadurl=yes}} ==See also== * [[University at Buffalo Stadium]] * [[Amherst Audubon Field]] ==Gallery== File:Alumni Arena UB.jpg|Alumni Arena with Score Board Improvements, 2012 File:UB vs Ohio 2006.jpg|Alumni Arena Student Section at Buffalo Bulls Basketball Game, January 2006 ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101214134231/http://buffalobulls.com/facilities/alumni_arena Alumni Arena - revision.comment: /* Medal table */ Converting to use [[Template:Medals table]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Athletics Championships |Name = I Africa Military Games |Logo = |Size = |Colour = |Optional caption = |Host city = [[Nairobi]], Kenya |Dates = 24–26 April 2002 |Stadium = [[Moi International Sports Centre]] |Nations participating = |Athletes participating = |Events = 26 |Games = [[Africa Military Games]] }} The '''[[Athletics (sport)|athletics competition]]''' at the '''[[Africa Military Games]]''' was held from 24–26 April 2002 at the [[Moi International Sports Centre]] in [[Nairobi]], Kenya.
A total of twenty-six events were contested, eighteen by men and eight by women. A near full [[track and field]] programme was held for men, with all regular track events being held and only the [[pole vault]] and [[hammer throw]] missing from the field events. The women's programme had limited entries so was mostly track running events, plus the [[long jump]] and [[high jump]]. No road or combined events were contested. All performances were affected by the high altitude of Nairobi.<ref name=GBR>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/afmg.htm Africa Military Games]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-01-30.</ref>
The hosts, Kenya, were dominant at the competition, winning seventeen of the 26 gold medals on offer, including all but three of the track titles. The next most successful nation was Morocco, which won three gold medals and four silvers, having particular success in the women's section. Botswana took three golds in the men's events and also had the third largest medal haul at five. Military athletes from thirteen nations reached the podium.<ref name=GBR/>
Kenya provided the foremost international athletes at the meeting. The [[Athletics at the 2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Sydney Olympics]] champion [[Noah Ngeny]] took the [[800 metres]] title. Olympic medallist and former world champion [[Wilson Boit Kipketer]] easily won the [[3000 metres steeplechase]]. Multiple world cross country medallist [[Paul Malakwen Kosgei]] was beaten to the [[10,000 metres]] gold by [[John Cheruiyot Korir]] – a situation that was reversed at the [[2002 African Championships in Athletics]] later that year. The [[5000 metres]] winner [[Sammy Kipketer]] later established himself globally with another win at the [[2002 Commonwealth Games]].<ref>Njenga, Peter (2002-04-27). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/ngeny-and-kipketers-plans-for-golden-doubles Ngeny and Kipketer's plans for golden doubles spoilt in Nairobi]. IAAF. Retrieved on 2015-01-27.</ref><ref>Njenga, Peter (2002-04-24). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/easy-5000m-win-for-kipketer Easy 5000m win for Kipketer]. IAAF. Retrieved on 2015-01-27.</ref>
The women's competition was of a lower standard, with the most prominent international athlete being 1500 m winner [[Naomi Mugo]], who formerly won a middle-distance double at the [[African Championships in Athletics]]. The reigning 800 m [[Mediterranean Games]] champion [[Seltana Aït Hammou]] was also present and won her speciality. [[IAAF World Cross Country Championships]] participants [[Restituta Joseph]], [[Anna Ndege]] and Olympian [[Nebiat Habtemariam]] were other globally established athletes to medal at the Africa Military Games.<ref name=GBR/>
The most successful athletes in the competition were [[Jacinta Wambui]] and [[David Kirui]], both of Kenya and both winners of a [[200 metres]]/[[400 metres]] sprint double.<ref name=GBR/>

{{For|the minor league ballpark in [[Boise, Idaho]]|Airway Park}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Braves Field | nickname = ''"The Wigwam"''
''"The Bee Hive"'' (1936–41) | image = Boston bleachers, Braves Field 2nd game of World Series, 10-9-16 (LOC) (15215977465).jpg | image_caption = Braves Field during the 1916 World Series | location = Commonwealth Avenue
and Babcock Street
[[Boston, Massachusetts]], U.S. | coordinates = {{coord|42.353|N|71.119|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = March 20, 1915 | opened = August 18, 1915
{{Years or months ago|1915}} | renovated = 1944, 1955 | expanded = | closed = September 21, 1952 | demolished = 1955  (reconfigured
into [[Nickerson Field]]) | owner = [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]]/[[Boston Bees]] | operator = Boston Braves/Bees | surface = Natural grass | architect = [[Osborn Engineering]] | construction_cost = $600,000 | former_names = [[National League]] Park
([[1936 Boston Bees season|1936]]–[[1941 Boston Braves season|1941]])
[[Boston University]] Field
(1953–1955) | tenants = '''Baseball'''
[[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) ([[1915 Boston Braves season|1915]]–[[1952 Boston Braves season|1952]])
'''Football'''
[[Boston Bulldogs (AFL)|Boston Bulldogs]] ([[American Football League (1926)|AFL]]) (1926)
[[Boston Bulldogs (NFL)|Boston Bulldogs]] (NFL) (1929)
[[Boston Braves (NFL)|Boston Braves]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]) ([[1932 Boston Braves (NFL) season|1932]])
[[Boston Shamrocks (AFL)|Boston Shamrocks]] (AFL) (1936–1937)
[[Boston Yanks]] (NFL) (1946, 1948) | seating_capacity = 40,000 | dimensions = ''Final''
'''Left field''' – {{Convert|337|ft|abbr=on}}
'''Left-center''' – {{Convert|355|ft|abbr=on}}
'''Center field''' – {{Convert|390|ft|0|abbr=on}}
'''Right-center''' – {{Convert|355|ft|abbr=on}}
'''Right field''' – {{Convert|319|ft|abbr=on}} |}} '''Braves Field''' was a [[baseball park]] in the [[Northeastern United States]], located in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. Today the site is home to [[Nickerson Field]] on the campus of [[Boston University]]. The stadium was home of the [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]] of the [[National League]] from [[1915 Boston Braves season|1915]]–[[1952 Boston Braves season|1952]], prior to the Braves' move to [[Milwaukee]] in [[1953 Milwaukee Braves season|1953]]. The stadium hosted the [[1936 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]] and Braves home games during the [[1948 World Series]]. The [[Boston Red Sox]] used Braves Field for their home games in the [[1915 World Series|1915]] and [[1916 World Series]] since the stadium had a larger seating capacity than [[Fenway Park]]. Braves Field was the site of [[Babe Ruth]]'s final season, playing for the Braves in 1935.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/BSN/1948.shtml|title=1948 Boston Braves Statistics - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/ruthba01.shtml|title=Babe Ruth Stats - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} From 1929 to 1932, the Boston Red Sox played select regular season games periodically at Braves Field.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/ballparks-braves-field.html|title=The Ballparks: Braves Field, Boston, Massachusetts|author=|date=|website=www.thisgreatgame.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} On May 1, 1920, Braves Field hosted the longest major league baseball game in history – 26 innings, which eventually ended in a 1–1 tie.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN192005010.shtml|title=Brooklyn Robins at Boston Braves Box Score, May 1, 1920 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} Braves Field was also home to multiple professional [[American football|football]] teams between 1929 and 1948, including the first home of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) franchise that became the [[Washington Redskins]]. The pro football Braves played at the ballpark in their inaugural season of [[1932 Boston Braves (NFL) season|1932]], then were at Fenway Park for four seasons as the [[1933 Boston Redskins season|Boston Redskins]] before the move south in [[1937 Washington Redskins season|1937]] to [[Griffith Stadium]] in Washington, D.C. Located on Commonwealth Avenue at Babcock Street, the baseball field was aligned northeast, much as Fenway Park has been since it opened in April 1912. Most of the stadium was demolished in 1955, but significant portions of the original structure still stand and make up part of the [[Nickerson Field]] sports complex on the campus of [[Boston University]]. ==Professional football== While built for baseball and having a rich baseball history, Braves Field briefly served as host for football teams. Braves Field was one of two homes (with [[Fenway Park]]) of the [[Boston Bulldogs (AFL)|Boston Bulldogs]] of the [[American Football League (1926)|first American Football League]] (in [[1926 American Football League season|1926]]) and the [[Boston Shamrocks (AFL)|Boston Shamrocks]] of the [[American Football League (1936)|second AFL]] (in 1936 and 1937). The [[National Football League]]'s [[Pottsville Maroons]] were sold and relocated to Braves Field in 1929 as the [[Boston Bulldogs (NFL)|Boston Bulldogs]]. In 1932, Braves Field became home of the football Boston Braves, a [[National Football League]] expansion franchise, owned by [[George Preston Marshall]]. The next year, after a 4–4–2 season, the Boston Braves Football franchise moved to [[Fenway Park]] and changed its name to the Redskins.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/wasbos/bosskins.html|title=Boston Redskins (1932-1936)|author=|date=|website=www.sportsecyclopedia.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} In 1937 the franchise relocated and become today's [[Washington Redskins]].{{cite web|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/was/1932.htm|title=1932 Boston Braves Statistics & Players - Pro-Football-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Pro-Football-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} Later, the [[Boston Yanks]] played a few games at Braves Field when [[Fenway Park]] was unavailable. The team was also the home of the [[Portland_Breakers#Boston_Breakers|USFL's Boston Breakers]] in the early 80's. ==Baseball history== [[File:Crowds at Braves Field Loop, opening day, 1915.jpg|thumb|left|Crowds at the streetcar loop outside the field on August 13, 1915, the first day of baseball in the new park]] Before the Braves became the first modern-era franchise to relocate, in 1952, the Boston Braves franchise had been in Boston since 1871. Before Braves Field, the franchise had played at [[South End Grounds]], with play at [[Congress Street Grounds]] in 1894 while [[South End Grounds]] was rebuilt following the May 15, 1894 Roxbury Fire .{{cite web|url=http://ballparks.com/baseball/national/sthend.htm|title=South End Grounds|author=|date=|website=ballparks.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} Shortly after the [[Boston Red Sox]] opened [[Fenway Park]] in 1912, Braves owner [[James E. Gaffney|James Gaffney]] purchased the former Allston Golf Club, one mile west of [[Fenway Park]] to build a new park for the Braves. Construction of the $600,000 Braves Field began on March 20, 1915 and was completed before the end of the 1915 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.ballparksofbaseball.com/past/BravesField.htm|title=Braves Field - History, Photos and more of the Boston Braves former ballpark|author=|date=|website=ballparksofbaseball.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bahistory.org/BravesField.html|title=Braves Field|author=|date=|website=www.bahistory.org|accessdate=17 March 2018}} The park was constructed entirely of steel (approx 750 tons) and an estimated 8 million pounds of concrete.{{cite web|url=http://sabr.org/research/braves-field-imperfect-history-perfect-ballpark|title=Braves Field: An Imperfect History of the Perfect Ballpark - Society for American Baseball Research|author=|date=|website=sabr.org|accessdate=17 March 2018}} Braves Field officially opened on August 18, 1915 with 46,000 in attendance to see the Braves defeat the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] 3-1.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN191508180.shtml|title=St. Louis Cardinals at Boston Braves Box Score, August 18, 1915 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} Braves Park was the largest stadium built in that era, with 40,000 capacity and a trolley system leading to the park. Braves Field was nicknamed ''The Wigwam'' by fans. Later it was nicknamed ''The Bee Hive'' and the name changed to '''National League Park''', from 1936–1941, a period during which the owners changed the nickname of the team to the Boston Bees. The renaming of the team and stadium were both eventually dropped. During this span, it hosted the fourth [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game]] in [[1936 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1936]]. With its capacity to hold more fans than [[Fenway Park]], Braves Field was used by the Red Sox in the [[1915 World Series|1915]] and [[1916 World Series]]; with Braves Field still under construction, the Braves had used Fenway Park for their World Series Title in [[1914 World Series|1914]]. [[File:Boston Braves field postcard.jpg|thumb|left|Postcard showing the lights shortly after installation in 1946/47.]] Looking at design, [[James E. Gaffney|James Gaffney]] wanted to see the game played in a wide open field conducive to allowing numerous inside-the-park home runs. Thus, the stadium was built in what was, at the time, the outskirts of Boston, in a large rectangular plot, contrasting with the cozy and lopsided block containing Fenway Park. The stands were almost entirely in foul territory, leaving little in the outfield to which players could hit a home run into – with the fences over {{convert|400|ft|-1}} away down the lines and nearly {{convert|500|ft|-1}} to dead center, hitting the ball over the outer fences was all but impossible during the [[dead-ball era]]. A stiff breeze coming in from center field across the [[Charles River]] further lessened any chances of seeing home runs fly out of the park.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ji4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24&dq=baseball+digest+shanty+hogan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1GlHT8_nJoW58gOIv4WQDg&ved=0CEoQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Diamonds Are Rough All Over |author=Frank, Stanley |publisher=|date=July 1947 |work=Baseball Digest |accessdate=24 February 2012 }} The only possible target in the outfield was a small [[bleacher]] section, which came to be known as ''The Jury Box'' after a sportswriter noticed during one slow mid-week game that there were only twelve individuals sitting in the 2,000-seat stand. [[Ty Cobb]] visited the park and commented, "Nobody will ever hit a ball out of this park." The large foul ground area further favored the pitchers. It took seven years and a livelier ball before a batter hit a home run that cleared the outer wall on the fly. [[1922 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] catcher [[Frank Snyder (baseball)|Frank Snyder]] hit the first major league home run in the history of Braves Field in {{Baseball year|1922}} when he cleared the [[left field]] foul pole. Meanwhile, it remained a pitchers' park, perhaps never more so than on May 1, 1920, when [[1920 Brooklyn Dodgers season|Brooklyn Dodgers]] pitcher [[Leon Cadore]] and Braves pitcher [[Joe Oeschger]] locked horns for a pair of complete-game performances that went on for a still-record 26 innings. After all that work, the game ended in a 1–1 tie, called on account of darkness. At the advent of the lively ball era, it became clear that the fans were unhappy with Gaffney's vision of how baseball should be played, and inner fences were built, and regularly moved, being moved in and out based on whims. Later, the ownership of the team even went so far as to shift the entire field in a clockwise direction (towards right field) at one point. One year after opening Braves Field, Gaffney had sold the Braves, but kept Braves Field. Gaffney and his heirs then leased the stadium out to Braves owners until 1949, when his heirs sold it back to the Braves for approx. $750,000. On Sunday, September 21, 1952, the Brooklyn Dodgers defeated the Braves, 8–2, before 8,822 fans in the final Major League game at Braves Field. [[Roy Campanella]] hit the last home run to help [[Joe Black]] defeat a Braves team with 20 year-old rookie [[Eddie Mathews]] hitting 3rd.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN195209210.shtml|title=Brooklyn Dodgers at Boston Braves Box Score, September 21, 1952 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} [[Image:BUNickersonConcourse.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The concourse under the ballpark's remaining seating area still exists almost exactly as it did when the Braves played there.]] [[File:Yankees vs. Athletics at Municipal Stadium.jpg|thumb|Yankees vs. K.C. Athletics at Municipal Stadium, August,1966. Former Braves Field Scoreboard visible at right]] [[File:NickersonField2.jpg|thumb|left|NickersonField, 2008, part of old Boston Braves Field.]] [[File:Bravesfieldplaque.JPG|thumb|left|Braves Field Plaque]] ==Closing and renovation== After purchasing the Braves from [[Bob Quinn (baseball)|Bob Quinn]] in 1945, owner [[Lou Perini]], citing low attendance, moved the Braves to [[Milwaukee]] just prior to the 1953 season, leaving Braves Field vacant. The Braves had drawn fewer than 300,000 fans in 1952, after drawing over 1 million in 1947,1948 and 1949. Milwaukee had been the site of the Braves' Minor League team, the [[Milwaukee Brewers]], and the Braves had earlier blocked an attempt by the [[St. Louis Browns]] to move to Milwaukee.{{cite web|url=http://www.brainyhistory.com/events/1953/march_3_1953_114332.html|title=Boston Braves, who own Milwaukee minor league... March 3 in History at BrainyHistory.com|author=|date=|website=brainyhistory.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/ATL/|title=Atlanta Braves Team History & Encyclopedia - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} With the Braves gone, [[Boston University]] quickly purchased the former home of the Braves on July 30, 1953, renaming it [[Boston University Field]] and utilizing it for their student athletes, a usage that remains today.http://www.ballparktour.com/Former_Boston.html The remaining scoreboard was sold and was moved to [[Kansas City Municipal Stadium]].{{cite book |title=Green Cathedrals |last=Lowry |first=Philip |year=2006 |publisher=Walker & Company |location= |isbn=978-0-8027-1608-8 |page=33 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Afo5vtVTz4wC&lpg=PP1&dq=green%20cathedrals&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false }} The old ballpark was used as-is until 1955, when [[Boston University]] reconfigured the stands and the grounds. The remodel replaced all but the pavilion grandstand at the end of the right field line, which was retained as the seating core of a football, soccer, field hockey, and track-and-field stadium. The stadium was initially called "Boston University Field" and later renamed [[Nickerson Field]]. Along with the pavilion, the original outer wall was retained, though a portion of that wall along what is now Harry Agganis Way was replaced with wrought iron fencing in 2008. The stadium's ticket office was converted into the [[Boston University]] police station. The rest of the stadium structure was replaced by dormitories covering the former main grandstand; and the Case Physical Education Center, which houses [[Walter Brown Arena]] and [[Case Gym]] in the vicinity of what was the left field pavilion along [[Babcock Street]]. Of the demolished [[Baseball park#Jewel box ballparks|Jewel Box ballparks]], Braves Field has the largest proportion of visible remnants still standing, as no other former ballpark has any portion of its seating still in use. ==World Series games== [[File:Boston Braves Baseball Team of 1948 (78732).jpg|thumb|Boston Braves baseball team of 1948]] [[World Series]] games were played at Braves Field in 1915, 1916, and 1948. The [[Boston Red Sox]] played their home games in the [[1915 World Series|1915]] and [[1916 World Series]] at the new Braves Field, as its capacity at the time was larger than [[Fenway Park]], while the Braves hosted three games of the [[1948 World Series]]. The Red Sox defeated the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] 4 games to 1 to win the 1915 World Series. On Monday, October 11, the Red Sox won Game 3 at Braves Field, 2–1, in front of 42,300. The next day, the Red Sox won Game 4 in front of 41,096, also 2–1.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1915_WS.shtml|title=1915 World Series - Boston Red Sox over Philadelphia Phillies (4-1) - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} As a young pitcher on the Red Sox, [[Babe Ruth]] only appeared in the series once, as a pinch hitter, going 0–1 in Game 1.{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/playerpost.php?p=ruthba01&ps=ws|title=Babe Ruth World Series Stats by Baseball Almanac|first=Baseball Almanac,|last=Inc.|date=|website=www.baseball-almanac.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} The following year, the Red Sox played the [[History of the Brooklyn Dodgers|Brooklyn Robins]] in the 1916 World Series. In Game 1, the Red Sox defeated Brooklyn, 6–5, at Braves Field in front of 36,117. On Monday, October 9, Boston left-hander Babe Ruth pitched against [[Sherry Smith]] in front of 47,373.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BOS/BOS191610090.shtml|title=1916 World Series Game 2, Brooklyn Robins at Boston Red Sox, October 9, 1916 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} Ruth and Smith dueled for 14 innings, before Ruth and the Red Sox won in the bottom of the 14th, 2–1. The Red Sox won their second consecutive World Series with a 4–1 victory in Game 5 at Braves Field, with 43,620 in attendance.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1916_WS.shtml|title=1916 World Series - Boston Red Sox over Brooklyn Robins (4-1) - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} [[File:Vern Bickford, Johnny Sain, Warren Spahn.png|thumb|Vern Bickford, Johnny Sain, Warren Spahn]] In 1948, the Boston Braves captured the National League pennant with 91 wins. The Braves then played the [[Cleveland Indians]] in the World Series, losing 4 games to 2. Two future Hall-of-Famers led their teams as Managers, [[Lou Boudreau]] of Indians and [[Billy Southworth]] leading the Braves.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1948_WS.shtml|title=1948 World Series - Cleveland Indians over Boston Braves (4-2) - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} The 1948 Braves were led by pitchers [[Johnny Sain]] and Hall-of-Famer [[Warren Spahn]]. In Game 1, on October 6, Sain beat [[Bob Feller]] of the Indians, 1–0, at Braves Field in front of 40,135. The Indians took Game 2, 4–1, the next day at Braves Field, with [[Bob Lemon]] beating Spahn with 39,633 in attendance. Game 2 also made television history when a live broadcast of the game was shown to passengers of the B&O Railroad's train traveling between Washington, D.C. and New York City.{{cite news |title=Train Television Shows Ball Game |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 8, 1948 }} The Braves and Indians returned to Boston for Game 6 on Monday October 11, 1948. The Indians defeated the Braves, 4–3, in front of 40,103 to capture the championship. ==1936 All-Star Game== On July 7, 1936 the [[1936 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]] was played at Braves Field, with 25,566 in attendance.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/allstar/1936-allstar-game.shtml|title=1936 All-Star Game Box Score, July 7 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} The National League defeated the American League, 4–3, in the 4th All-Star game, featuring over 20 future [[Major League Baseball Hall of Fame]] members. [[Lefty Grove]] and [[Dizzy Dean]] were the starting pitchers for managers [[Joe McCarthy (manager)|Joe McCarthy]] of the [[New York Yankees]] and [[Charlie Grimm]] of the [[Chicago Cubs]].{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/allstar/|title=All-Star Game History and Leaders - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} [[Lou Gehrig]] hit a home run for the American League, batting behind rookie [[Joe DiMaggio]] in the lineup. Among others, [[Luke Appling]], [[Bill Dickey]], [[Joe Cronin]], [[Schoolboy Rowe]], [[Jimmie Foxx]], [[Rick Ferrell]], [[Earl Averill]] and [[Charlie Gehringer]] were selected for the American League. The National League roster included [[Billy Herman]], [[Joe Medwick]], [[Gabby Hartnett]], [[Arky Vaughan]], [[Goose Goslin]], [[Leo Durocher]], [[Ernie Lombardi]], [[Mel Ott]] and [[Carl Hubbell]]. ==Longest Major League game== On Saturday, May 1, 1920, at Braves Field, the Braves and [[History of the Brooklyn Dodgers|Brooklyn Robins]] played 26 complete innings in a game that ended in a 1–1 tie, called due to darkness by home plate umpire [[Barry McCormick]].{{cite web|url=http://www.todayifoundout.com/index.php/2012/11/the-longest-game-in-baseball-history/|title=The Longest Game by Innings in Major League Baseball History|author=|date=20 November 2012|website=todayifoundout.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1920/B05010BSN1920.htm |title=Boston Braves 1, Brooklyn Robins 1 |website=[[Retrosheet]] |date=May 1, 1920}} It is the longest game, by innings, in Major League history.{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/recbooks/rb_gmlg.shtml |title=Game Length Records |website=[[Baseball Almanac]] |accessdate=October 20, 2017}} Starting pitchers [[Leon Cadore]] (Brooklyn) and [[Joe Oeschger]] (Boston) both pitched the entire game in front of 4,500 fans. The 26 innings by both pitchers is also a record,{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/recbooks/rb_ip.shtml |title=Innings Pitched Records |website=[[Baseball Almanac]] |accessdate=October 20, 2017}} and it is conservatively estimated that each threw at least 300 pitches.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/sweetspot/post/_/id/35687/the-day-the-pitchers-went-26-innings|title=The day the pitchers went 26 innings|author=|date=|website=go.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} Oeschager threw 21 consecutive scoreless innings in the game, Cadore threw 20. Second baseman [[Charlie Pick]] of the Braves went 0–11, the worst single day at the plate in MLB history. Cadore faced 95 Braves hitters, while Oeschager faced 90 hitters. Brooklyn and the Braves met again on Monday, May 3, after an off-day for the Braves. That game lasted another 19 innings, a 2–1 Boston win.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN192005030.shtml|title=Brooklyn Robins at Boston Braves Box Score, May 3, 1920 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} In between, on Sunday, May 2, Brooklyn played at home against Philadelphia (a 4–3 Brooklyn win) in a game that went 13 innings.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/games/standings.cgi?year=1920&month=5&day=2&submit=Submit+Date|title=MLB Scores, Standings, Box Scores for Sunday, May 2, 1920 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} This gave Brooklyn 58 innings played in three days and three games. ==No-hitters== There were four [[no-hitter]]s pitched at Braves Field, none of them was a [[perfect game]]; {| class="wikitable" ! Date || Pitcher || Team || Score || Opponent || Attendance || Ref. |- | June 16, 1916 || [[Tom Hughes (pitcher, born 1884)|Tom Hughes]] || Boston Braves || 2–0 || [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] ||  N/A ||{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN191606160.shtml|title=Pittsburgh Pirates at Boston Braves Box Score, June 16, 1916 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} |- | April 27, 1944 || [[Jim Tobin]] || Boston Braves || 2–0 || [[Brooklyn Dodgers]] ||  1,447 ||{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN194404270.shtml|title=Brooklyn Dodgers at Boston Braves Box Score, April 27, 1944 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14556331/jim_tobins_nohit_norun_game_sees/ |title=Jim Tobin's No-Hit, No-Run Game Sees Only 98 Pitches Delivered |newspaper=[[Sentinel & Enterprise|Fitchburg Sentinel]] |location=[[Fitchburg, Massachusetts]] |date=April 28, 1944 |accessdate=October 20, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}} |- | August 11, 1950 || [[Vern Bickford]] || Boston Braves || 7–0 || Brooklyn Dodgers || 29,208 ||{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN195008110.shtml|title=Brooklyn Dodgers at Boston Braves Box Score, August 11, 1950 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} |- | May 6, 1951{{dagger}} || [[Cliff Chambers]] || Pittsburgh Pirates || 3–0 || Boston Braves || 15,492 ||{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN195105062.shtml|title=Pittsburgh Pirates at Boston Braves Box Score, May 6, 1951 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} |} :{{dagger}} Second game of a [[Doubleheader (baseball)|doubleheader]] ==3-home-run games== There were only two three-home-run games at Braves Field; {| class="wikitable" ! Date || Player || Team || Score || Opponent || Attendance || Ref. |- | June 2, 1928 || [[Les Bell]]{{dagger}} || Boston Braves || 12–20 || [[Cincinnati Reds]] || 18,000 ||{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN192806020.shtml|title=Cincinnati Reds at Boston Braves Box Score, June 2, 1928 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} |- | May 13, 1942 || [[Jim Tobin]]{{double dagger}} || Boston Braves ||  6–5 || [[Chicago Cubs]] ||  3,443 ||{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/BSN/BSN194205130.shtml|title=Chicago Cubs at Boston Braves Box Score, May 13, 1942 - Baseball-Reference.com|author=|date=|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} |} :{{dagger}} Bell also hit a triple. :{{double dagger}} Tobin is the only modern era (post-1900) pitcher to hit three home runs in one game. ==Dimensions== As noted above, the fences were moved repeatedly throughout the ballpark's existence, sometimes within a given season.{{cn|date=October 2017}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" ! {{Infobox film | name = Brooklyn Castle | image = Brooklyn Castle Promotional Poster.jpg | alt = Promotional Poster for Brooklyn Castle | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = Katie Dellamaggiore | producer = Katie Dellamaggiore
Nelson Dellamaggiore
Brian Schulz | screenplay = | based on = | starring = {{unbulleted list|[[Rochelle Ballantyne]]|[[Justus Williams]]|[[James Black, Jr.]]}} | music = B. Satz | cinematography = Brian Schulz | editing = Nelson Dellamaggiore | studio = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2012|03|11|South by Southwest Film Festival|2012|10|19|United States}} | runtime = 101 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Brooklyn Castle''''' ([[2012 in film|2012]]) is a [[documentary film]] about [[Intermediate School 318]], an inner-city public school in [[Brooklyn, New York]]. Where an after-school chess program, having both dedicated educators and a supportive community, has triumphed over deep budget cuts to build the most winning junior high school chess team in the country,[http://nantucketfilmfestival.org/index.php/home/in-the-news/89-brooklyn-castle-winning-games-and-hearts Winning Games and Winning Hearts] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120626063129/http://nantucketfilmfestival.org/index.php/home/in-the-news/89-brooklyn-castle-winning-games-and-hearts |date=June 26, 2012 }} and the first middle school team to win the [[United States Chess Federation|United States Chess Federation's]] national high school championship. The film follows five of the school's chess team members for one year, and documents their challenges and triumphs both on and off the chessboard. Remake rights have been acquired by [[Sony Pictures]] and producer [[Scott Rudin]].[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/risky-business/sxsw-2012-sony-scott-rudin-brooklin-castle-298619 Sony and Scott Rudin Acquire Remake Rights to 'Brooklyn Castle'] Rudin's other works include co-producing the acclaimed film ''[[Searching for Bobby Fischer]]'' (1993). ''Brooklyn Castle'' premiered at the [[South by Southwest|South by Southwest (SXSW)]] film festival on March 11, 2012. Over the next several months it was shown during at least eleven other film festivals winning a total of three festival awards to date.[http://www.brooklyncastle.com/press 'Brooklyn Castle' Awards] The film was released to a limited number of U.S. theaters on October 19, 2012.[http://www.brooklyncastle.com/see-the-film 'Brooklyn Castle' in Theaters on October 19, 2012] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831115734/http://www.brooklyncastle.com/see-the-film |date=August 31, 2012 }} ==Reception== Currently, the film has a rating of 96% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 45 reviews and an average score of 7.6/10.{{Cite web| title=Brooklyn Castle Movie Reviews |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/brooklyn_castle_2012/ |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Flixster]] |accessdate=December 23, 2012}} [[Tim_Ferriss#Tools_of_Titans|Tools of Titans]] by Timothy Ferriss indicates Brooklyn Castle is the favorite film of [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.brooklyncastle.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1800266|Brooklyn Castle}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|brooklyn_castle_2012}} * [http://www.chessintheschools.org Chess in the Schools] {{DEFAULTSORT:Brooklyn Castle}} [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:Films about chess]] [[Category:Chess in the United States]] [[Category:Documentary films about children]] [[Category:Documentary films about New York City]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about education in the United States]] [[Category:Films set in Brooklyn]] [[Category:Kickstarter-funded documentaries]] [[Category:2012 in chess]] {{documentary-film-stub}}

'''Busaiteen''' ({{lang-ar|البسيتين}}) is a [[Bahrain]]i club based in [[Busaiteen]]. The club competes in [[association football|football]], [[Volleyball]], [[Table Tennis]], and [[Track and Field|Track & Field]].
==Football Team==
Busiateen Club competes in the [[Bahraini Premier League]], and it is considered to be one of the main contenders for the title each year. The club possess several International players which contributed with the national team for many years But now the team is drop down to the 2nd Division League since 2015 / 2016 in Football Game and Compete in all Other Sports In The Club .

{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Campbell Field | nickname = | image = [[Image:Brooks Field 2008.jpg|200px|center]] | location = [[Golden, Colorado]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|45|11|N|105|13|39|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = February 1893 | opened = May 20, 1893 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Colorado School of Mines]] | operator = Colorado School of Mines | surface = Turf | construction_cost = | architect = William "Cement Bill" Williams (1922–24 grandstands) | former_names = Athletic Park (1893–1922), Brooks Field (1922–2010) | tenants = [[Colorado School of Mines]] Orediggers (1893–present)
(1893–1936: [[Baseball]], [[Soccer]]) | seating_capacity = 4000 |}} '''Campbell Field''', officially '''Marv Kay Stadium at Harry D. Campbell Field''', is an American college football stadium located in [[Golden, Colorado]]. The stadium serves as the home field of the [[Colorado Mines Orediggers]] football team representing the [[Colorado School of Mines]]. Campbell Field is one of the oldest [[American football|football]] fields in existence, the oldest west of the [[Mississippi River]] and the oldest in [[NCAA Division II]].{{cite web|title=Marv Kay Stadium at Harry D. Campbell Field|url=http://csmorediggers.com/Facilities/Campbell_Field|website=Colorado School of Mines athletics|accessdate=2 April 2016}} Originally it was a dirt surface all-purpose athletic field in exactly its current configuration, built within a clay pit, a fitting mined-out home for the Orediggers. Its first athletic contest, held on May 20, 1893, was the first annual Colorado Inter-Collegiate Athletic Association Field Day, featuring many athletic contests between the [[University of Colorado]], [[Colorado State University|Colorado A&M]], [[Colorado School of Mines]], and the [[University of Denver]], in which Mines claimed the most medals. Its first football game took place on October 7, 1893, a 6-0 Mines victory over the University of Denver. It has been home to the football Orediggers through all but the first five seasons of their existence (their previous home were the now-destroyed grounds at the southeast corner of 19th and Illinois streets in Golden), and has been renovated several times throughout its existence. The field was originally called Athletic Park, renamed Brooks Field after Mines trustee and benefactor Ralph D. Brooks in 1922, and renamed Campbell Field after 1939 undefeated team member and benefactor Harry D. Campbell in 2010. Harry D. Campbell also was a football teammate of the legendary Jackie Robinson at Pasadena Junior College. Campbell Field is the oldest football field in the west, the oldest in [[NCAA Division II]] football and the 5th oldest college football field in the nation. ==Renovations== Historic photographs show Brooks Field as a dirt surface, without grandstands and surrounded by a board fence. Despite such conditions it is known to have hosted crowds of spectators, who could have used nearby slopes to view games from. Later early wooden grandstands were added to the park. In 1922 and 1924 the current grandstands were built by noted local builder William "Cement Bill" Williams. This featured wooden bench seats upon a steel superstructure, with home and visiting locker rooms, public restrooms and refreshment stand beneath. In 1922 the dirt surface was converted to natural grass, part of which was scraped back to dirt surface for a [[baseball diamond]] during season each year. Originally home also to the CSM [[baseball]] team, it became a primarily football facility in 1937 after baseball was moved to [[Darden Field]] just to the west. During the 1930s a [[Federal Emergency Relief Administration]] project scooped out the slopes at the west side of Brooks Field to make room to construct a track around the surface, and it has hosted track and field events since. Around the 1980s the grandstands were renovated to cover most wooden benches with metal surfaces and create a central concourse, along with steps down to the field level. In 2010, the field was converted to its third surface, synthetic turf. Plans are underway to replace the 90-year-old grandstands and update the historic field to a state-of-the-art Division II athletic facility, expanding its capacity to 5,000, to be rechristened Marv Kay Stadium at Campbell Field. ==Notable Events== Campbell Field has hosted many notable athletes and teams over its many years of play. Although missing out on the legendary 103-0 victory of the Orediggers over the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]] in 1890 as well as their first Colorado Football Association championship in 1891, it has hosted 14 championship football teams and more: * Campbell Field hosted the latter part of the Orediggers' 18-game football winning streak against collegiate teams that spanned from 1888–1894. * The 3rd perfect and 4th unbeaten season of the football Orediggers took place here in its inaugural season in 1893 (5-0-0, CFA Champions). * Campbell Field hosted the latter half of the football Orediggers' streak of 6 winning seasons from 1888–1894. * CSM's earliest known football loss at Campbell Field took place in 1894 to the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]] (a 20-0 shutout). * The first live televised football game in the Rocky Mountain region took place here on November 1, 1952, a game between the Orediggers and [[Idaho State University]]. * The first live nationally televised football game in the Rocky Mountain region took place here on November 15, 1952, a game between the Orediggers and [[Colorado College]]. * The only football playoff game at Campbell Field took place on November 13, 2004 as the Orediggers beat [[Midwestern State University]]. ==Notable people== * [[Baltimore Colts]] (held training camp here in 1972) * [[Leroy Taylor Brown]], Olympic silver medalist, men's high jump, Paris 1924 (trained here as Mines graduate student prior to Olympics) * [[Earl "Dutch" Clark|Dutch Clark]], [[Pro football hall of fame]] (football coach at Mines in 1933) * [[Dallas Cowboys]] (held training camp here in the 1970s) * [[Denver Broncos]] (held training camp here from 1960–1963) * [[Chad Friehauf]], 2004 [[Harlon Hill Trophy]] winner (Mines quarterback) * [[Roy Hartzell]], Major League Baseball utility player, [[Baltimore Orioles#St. Louis Browns|St. Louis Browns]], [[New York Yankees|New York Highlanders/Yankees]] (played semipro ball for Golden Reds here) * [[Cowboy Jones|Albert E. Jones]], Major League Baseball pitcher, [[Cleveland Spiders]], [[St. Louis Cardinals|St. Louis Perfectos/Cardinals]] (played semipro ball for Golden Reds here) * [[Jack Liddle]], Olympic runner, Berlin 1936 (trained here as Mines student prior to Olympics) * [[Lloyd Madden]], National Football League player, [[Chicago Cardinals (NFL, 1920–59)|Chicago Cardinals]] (played here as Mines student) * [[Mark Melancon]], Major League Baseball pitcher, [[New York Yankees]], [[Houston Astros]], [[Boston Red Sox]] (played here as Golden High School football player) * [[Elwood Romney]], Brigham Young University hall of fame basketball player and All-American, cousin of [[Mitt Romney]] (coached freshman football 1936–1939) ===Championship Football Teams=== The Orediggers have fielded 16 football champion teams within over a century of play: '''1891''' – Colorado Football Association Champions^
'''1892''' – Colorado Football Association Champions^
'''1893''' – Colorado Football Association Champions
'''1897''' – State Inter-Collegiate League Champions

'''1914''' – [[Rocky Mountain Athletic Conference]] Champions

'''1939''' – [[Rocky Mountain Athletic Conference]] Champions

She represents her nation at international competitions.
She participated at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London. She also competed at world championships, including at the 2010 and [[2011 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships athletes - Eliora Zholkovsky|url=http://gym.longinestiming.com/File/00000A010100FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF02|publisher=Longinestiming.com|date= |accessdate=27 January 2016}}</ref>

'''Football South West Queensland''' is a [[Football Queensland]] administrative zone encompassing cities and shires from the [[Toowoomba]], [[Darling Downs]] and [[South West Queensland]]. The main competition of the region is in Toowoomba with smaller surrounding cities also competing, however Roma and other towns have their own league programs running.
==Football Toowoomba==
Football Toowoomba is the main football organisation of the region. It is responsible for the running of junior and senior leagues, junior development programs, referee programs and coaching.
There are junior and senior clubs in the region, offering football for both male and female competitors.

'''1st:''' €40,000 }} The '''Goldene Peitsche''' is a [[Conditions races|Group 3]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[Germany]] open to [[thoroughbred]]s aged three years or older. It is run at [[Baden-Baden]] over a distance of 1,200 metres (about 6 furlongs), and it is scheduled to take place each year in late August or early September. ==History== The event was established in 1867, and the inaugural running was won by Cobweb. It was initially held at [[Tempelhof]], and was transferred to [[Hoppegarten]] in 1868. The race was switched to [[Grunewald]] in 1918, and it returned to Hoppegarten in 1923. It was not run from 1945 to 1947, and for brief spells thereafter it was staged at [[Cologne]] (1948) and [[Mülheim]] (1949, 1950 and 1952). The Goldene Peitsche moved to Baden-Baden in 1953. It was given Group 3 status in 1973, and was promoted to Group 2 level in 1991. It was downgraded to Group 3 in 2014 only.{{cite web|title=Upgrades / downgrades for 2014 |url=http://www.britishhorseracing.presscentre.com/imagelibrary/downloadMedia.ashx?MediaDetailsID=262 |website=britishhorseracing.presscentre.com |accessdate=30 June 2014 }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} But returned Group 2 in 2015, during Sprint Races programme update.[http://www.britishhorseracing.com/press_releases/british-racing-welcomes-addition-two-group-1-races-boost-sprint-programme/ European Pattern Committee announce major changes to sprint programme from 2015 / 13 Aug 14] In August 2018, Raven's Lady from England won the 148th Casino Baden-Baden Golden Whip.{{Cite news|url=https://www.welt.de/regionales/baden-wuerttemberg/article181315136/Favoritin-Raven-s-Lady-gewinnt-Goldene-Peitsche-in-Iffezheim.html|title=Favoritin Raven's Lady gewinnt Goldene Peitsche in Iffezheim|last=WELT|date=2018-08-26|work=DIE WELT|access-date=2018-10-16}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.focus.de/sport/mehrsport/reiten-national-galopp-ravens-lady-gewinnt-goldene-peitsche_id_9477396.html|title=Galopp: Raven's Lady gewinnt Goldene Peitsche|last=Online|first=FOCUS|work=FOCUS Online|access-date=2018-10-16|language=de}} ==Records==
